ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.2_0: At one time a number of monks who were friends had entered the rainy-season residence on the slopes of Isigili. They entered the rains residence together.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.3_0: Among them was Venerable Dhaniya the potter.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.4_0: After three months, when they had completed the rainy-season residence, the monks demolished their grass huts, put away the grass and wood, and left to wander in the country.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.5_0: But Venerable Dhaniya also spent the winter and the summer there.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.6_0: Then, on one occasion, while Dhaniya was in the village to collect almsfood, some women gathering grass and firewood demolished the grass hut and took away the grass and sticks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.7_0: A second time Dhaniya collected grass and sticks and made a grass hut,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.8_0: and again the hut was demolished in the same way.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.9_0: The same thing happened a third time.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.13_0: I’m well-trained, tied, infatuated, and cleansed my teacher’s trade.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.14_0: Why don’t I knead mud myself and make a hut consisting of nothing but clay?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.15_0: Then Dhaniya did just that. And he collected grass, wood, and cow-dung, and he baked his hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.16_0: It was a beautiful and charming little hut, and it was red just like a scarlet rain-mite.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.1.17_0: And when hit it sounded just like the sound of a bell.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.1_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha was descending from the Vulture Peak with a number of monks and he saw that hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.3_0: “Monks, what’s this beautiful and charming thing, which is red like a scarlet rain-mite?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.6_0: “It’s not suitable for that foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.7_0: How can he make a hut out of nothing but clay?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.8_0: Certainly that foolish man can have no consideration, compassion, and mercy for living beings.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.9_0: Go, monks, and demolish this hut,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.10_0: so that future generations don’t take up the destruction of living beings.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.11_0: But, monks, you should not make a hut out of nothing but clay.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.12_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.13_0: “Yes, Venerable Sir,” the monks replied, and they went to their huts.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.13_1: and after going, they demolished that hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.2.17_0: “Demolish it, if the Lord of the Truth has said so.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.3_0: I’ve laid down all kinds of huts by the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.4_0: But the caretaker of the woodyard is a friend of mine.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.5_0: Why don’t I ask him for timber and make a hut out of that?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.6_0: Dhaniya then went to the caretaker of the woodyard.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.6_1: and after approaching he said this to the woodyard:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.8_0: I’ve laid down all kinds of huts by the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.10_0: I want to make a wooden hut.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.11_0: “There’s no such timber, Sir, that I could give you.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.12_0: This timber is held by the King, and it’s meant for the repair of the town and put aside in case of an emergency.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.13_0: You can only take it if the King gives it away.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.16_0: “These Sakyan ascetics live according to the Truth. They’re celibate and their conduct is good, and they’re truthful, moral, and have a good character.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.17_0: Even the King has faith in them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.18_0: Don’t steal what is given to others.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.3.21_0: Dhaniya then had that timber cut into pieces, removed it by means of carts, and made a wooden hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.1_0: Soon afterwards the brahmin Vassakāra, the chief minister of Magadha, while inspecting the works in Rājagaha, went to the caretaker of the woodyard.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.1_1: and after approaching he said this to the woodyard:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.3_0: The town-dwellers of the city meters took up residence in the repair of the town and put aside in case of an emergency.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.4_0: “Sir, that timber was given by the King to Venerable Dhaniya.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.5_0: Soon afterwards the brahmin Vassakāra was upset and thought,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.6_0: “How could the King give away this timber to Dhaniya the potter?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.7_0: So he went to King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.8_0: “Is it true, sir, that the timber held by the King, meant for the repair of the town and put aside in case of an emergency, was given by the King to Dhaniya the potter?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.11_0: “Well then, brahmin, send for the caretaker of the woodyard.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.12_0: And Vassakāra had the caretaker of the woodyard bound and taken by force.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.13_0: Dhaniya saw the caretaker of the woodyard being bound and taken by force,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.4.16_0: “Because of that business with the timber, Sir.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.1_0: Dhaniya then went to King Bimbisāra’s house.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.2_0: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha went to see him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.2_1: Then he went to Dhaniya, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.4_0: “Is it true, Venerable, that I have given the timber held by the King—meant for the repair of the town and put aside in case of an emergency—to you?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.7_0: He should give a share of rice.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.9_0: “Do you remember, great king, when you were first anointed, speaking these words:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.10_0: ‘I give the grass, sticks, and water for the ascetics and brahmins to enjoy.’?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.12_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who have a sense of conscience, who are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.13_0: They are afraid of wrongdoing even in regard to small matters.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.14_0: What was uttered by me was meant for these, and it concerned what’s ownerless in the wilderness.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.15_0: Yet you imagine that you can take timber not given to you by means of this pretext?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.16_0: But how could I presume to beat, imprison, or banish an ascetic or a brahmin living in my kingdom?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.17_0: Go, you’re free because of your status,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.5.18_0: but don’t do such a thing again.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.1_0: People complained and criticized the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.2_0: “These Sakyan ascetics are shameless and immoral liars.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.3_0: They claim to live according to the Truth, to be celibate and of good conduct, to be truthful, moral, and of good character.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.4_0: They have no asceticism, they have no spirituality,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.5_0: Asceticism and spirituality are lost to them!
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.6_0: Where is their asceticism, where their spirituality?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.8_0: What do they take these (others)s and others?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.9_0: The monks heard the complaints of those people
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.10_0: The monks of few desires who had a sense of conscience, who were contented, afraid of wrongdoing, and fond of the training, complained and criticized Venerable Dhaniya,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.11_0: “How can he take timber belonging to the King that hasn’t been given to him?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.12_0: After criticizing Dhaniya in many ways, they told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.13_0: The Buddha then convened the Sangha of monks and questioned Venerable Dhaniya:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.14_0: “Is it true, Dhaniya, that you’ve taken timber belonging to the King that wasn’t given to you?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.17_0: “It’s not suitable, foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.18_0: How can you take timber belonging to the King that hasn’t been given to you?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.19_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.20_0: but it will hinder confidence in those without it, and it will cause some with confidence to change their minds.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.21_0: Just then a former judge who had gone forth with the monks was sitting near the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.23_0: “For what amount of stealing does King Bimbisāra beat, imprison, or banish a thief?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.24_0: “For a _pāda_ coin, Sir, for the worth of a _pāda_, or for more than a _pāda_.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.25_0: At that time in Rājagaha a _pāda_ coin was worth five _māsaka_ coins.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.26_0: Then, after criticizing Dhaniya in many ways for being difficult to support ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.27_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.28.1_0: ‘If a monk, intending to steal, takes from one who has not been given to him—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.29_0: the sort of stealing for which kings, having caught a thief, would beat, imprison, or banish him, saying, “You’re a bandit, you’re a fool, you’ve gone astray, you’re a thief”—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.30_0: he too is expelled and excluded from the community.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:1.6.31_0: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.1_0: At one time monks from the group of six went to the dyers’ spread of cloth, took the dyers’ goods to the monastery, and shared it out.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.4_0: And you have been given much robe-cloth.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.5_0: “This has nothing to do with merit.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.6_0: Just now we went to the dyers’ spread of cloth and took the dyers’ goods.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.7_0: “Hasn’t a training rule been laid down by the Buddha?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.8_0: Why then do you take the dyers’ goods?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.9_0: “It’s true that a training rule has been laid down by the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.10_0: but it concerns inhabited areas, not the wilderness.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.12_0: It’s not suitable, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.13_0: How can you take the dyers’s goods?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.14_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.15_0: but it will hinder confidence in those without it and it will cause some with confidence to change their minds.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.16_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.17_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks from the group of six:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.18_0: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.21_0: “It’s not suitable, foolish men, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.22_0: How can you go to the dyers’ spread of cloth and take the dyers’ goods?
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.23_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it or increase the confidence of those who have it,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.24_0: but it will hinder confidence in those without it, and it will cause some with confidence to change their minds.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.25_0: Then, after rebuking the monks from the group of six in many ways, the Buddha spoke in dispraise of being difficult to support ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.26_0: but he spoke in praise ... of being energetic. Having given a teaching on what is right and proper, he addressed the monks ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.27_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.28.1_0: ‘If a monk, intending to steal, takes from an inhabited area or from the wilderness what has not been given to him—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.29_0: the sort of stealing for which kings, having caught a thief, would beat, imprison, or banish him, saying, “You’re a bandit, you’re a fool, you’ve gone astray, you’re a thief”—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:2.30_0: he too is expelled and excluded from the community.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.4_0: ...The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.6_0: an inhabited area of one hut, an inhabited area of two huts, an inhabited area of three huts, an inhabited area of four huts, an inhabited area with people, an inhabited area without people, an enclosed inhabited area, an unenclosed inhabited area, a disorganized inhabited area, and even a caravan settled for more than four months is called “an inhabited area”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.8_0: of an enclosed inhabited area: the outward stone-throw of a man of average stone.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.9_0: of an unenclosed inhabited area: the outward stone-throw of a man of average height standing in the vicinity of a house.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.11_0: apart from inhabited areas and the vicinity of inhabited areas, the remainder is called “the wilderness”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.13_0: what has not been given, what has not been let go of, what has not been relinquished; what is guarded, what is protected, what is regarded as “mine”; what belongs to someone else.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.13_1: This is called “what has not been given”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.15_0: the thought of stealing, the thought of taking.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.17_0: They’d carry off the crimes, the wind wafter it down on the spot.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.19_0: a _pāda_ coin, the worth of a _pāda_, or more than a _pāda_.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.21_0: kings of the earth, kings of a region, rulers of islands, rulers of border areas, judges, government officials, or whoever metes out physical punishment—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.23_0: whoever, intending to steal, takes anything having a value of five _māsaka_ coins or more than five _māsaka_ coins that has not been given—he is called “a thief”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.25_0: would beat with the hand, the foot, a whip, a cane, a cudgel, or by mutilation.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.27_0: would imprison by constricting with a rope, by constricting with shackles, by constricting with chains, by constricting to a house, by constricting to a city, by constricting to a village, by constricting to a town, by being guarded.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.29_0: would banish from a village, from a town, from a city, from a country, or from a district.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.30_0: You’re a bandit, you’re a fool, you’ve gone astray, you’re a thief:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.33_0: a _pāda_ coin, the worth of a _pāda_, or more than a _pāda_.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.35_0: When someone takes what’s given, we crush the good and playful to the posture.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.37_0: this is said with reference to the preceding offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.39_0: just as a fallen, withered leaf is incapable of becoming green again,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.40_0: so too a monk who, intending to steal, takes a _pāda_ coin, the worth of a _pāda_, or more than a _pāda_ that had not been given to him, is not an ascetic, not a son of the Sakyan.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.40_1: Therefore it is said, “he is expelled”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.42_0: Community: joint legal procedures, a joint recitation, the same training—this is called “community”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:3.43_0: He does not take part in this—therefore it is called “excluded from the community”.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.1.1_0: the ground in the open is covered with irrigation, in the openings, the boat, the smooth on the ground, the water in their, the fire, the air, and the sense. And they provide a large deportment in a neighborhood of villages, towns, cities, and many-tongued.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.2_0: the goods have been put down into the ground, buried, concealed.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.3_0: If, intending to steal, he thinks, “I’ll take the goods in the ground,” and he seeks for a companion, or he seeks for a spade or a basket, or he just goes to the goods, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.4_0: If he breaks a piece of wood or a creeper growing there, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.5_0: If he digs the soil or heaps it up or removes it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.6_0: If he touches the pot, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.7_0: If he makes it quiver, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.8_0: If he moves them from their base, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.9_0: If, intending to steal, he puts his own vessel into the pot and touches something worth five _māsaka_ coins or more than five _māsakas_, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.10_0: If he makes it quiver, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.11_0: If he makes it enter his own vessel or takes it with his fist, there is an offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.12_0: If, intending to steal, he touches goods made of string—an ornamental hanging string, a necklace, an ornamental girdle, a wrap garment, or a turban—he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.13_0: If he makes it quiver, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.14_0: If he grasps it at the top and pulls it, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.15_0: If, while rubbing it, he lifts it, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.16_0: If he removes the goods even as much as a hair’s breadth over the rim of the pot, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.17_0: If, intending to steal, he drinks—in a single action—ghee, oil, honey, or syrup having a value of five _māsaka_ coins or more than five _māsakas_, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.2.18_0: If he destroys it, throws it away, burns it, or renders it useless, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.3.2_0: the goods have been put down on the ground.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.3.3_0: If, intending to steal, he thinks, “I’ll steal the goods on the ground,” and he either searches for a companion or just goes there himself, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.3.4_0: if he touches it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.3.5_0: If he makes it quiver, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.3.6_0: If he moves them from their base, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.2_0: the goods are in the air—
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.3_0: Roja, a peacock, a peg, a whirlpool, or a golden waist, or a silver post.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.4_0: If, intending to steal, he thinks, “I’ll steal the goods in the air,” and he either searches for a companion or just goes there himself, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.5_0: If he cuts off their course of movement, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.6_0: if he touches it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.7_0: If he makes it quiver, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.4.8_0: If he moves them from their base, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:4.5.3_0: on a bed, on a bench, on a bamboo robe-rack, on a clothesline, on a wall peg, in a tree, or even just on a bowl rest.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.37.1_0: On one occasion a monk went to a meadow and, intending to steal it, he took some cut grass worth five _māsaka_ coins.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.37.4_0: On one occasion a monk went to a meadow and, intending to steal it, he cut grass worth five _māsaka_ coins and took it away.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.38.1_0: On one occasion some newly arrived monks divided up the mangoes belonging to the Sangha and ate them.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.38.2_0: The resident monks accused them, saying,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.38.8_0: “There’s no offense for one who thinks something is meant for eating.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.39.1_0: On one occasion the keepers of a mango-grove gave a mango to some monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.39.2_0: The monks, thinking, “They have the authority to guard, but not to give,”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.39.5_0: “There’s no offense when it’s a gift from a guardian.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.39.15_0: “There’s no offense when it’s a gift from a guardian.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.40.1_0: On one occasion a monk borrowed a piece of wood belonging to the Sangha and used it to support the wall of his own dwelling.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.40.7_0: “Sir, it’s time for me to speak.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.40.8_0: “There’s no offense for one who is borrowing.”

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.43.1_0: At one time the monks used elsewhere the furniture belonging to a certain lay follower.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.43.2_0: Then that lay follower complained and criticized him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.43.3_0: “How can those Venerables use furniture where it doesn’t belong?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.43.5_0: “You should not use furniture where it doesn’t belong.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.43.6_0: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.44.1_0: Soon afterwards, being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not respond today on the observance day.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.44.2_0: Their limbs and robes became dirty.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.1_0: On one occasion at Campā, a nun who was a pupil of the nun Thullanandā went to a family that supported Thullanandā and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.2_0: “The Venerable wants to drink the threefold pungent rice porridge.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.3_0: When it was ready, she took it away and ate it herself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.4_0: When Thullanandā found out about this, she accused her, saying,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.8_0: The nuns then told the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.9_0: They in turn told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.11_0: for every statement he commits an offense entailing confession.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.12_0: On one occasion in Rājagaha, a nun who was a pupil of the nun Thullanandā went to a family that supported Thullanandā and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.13_0: “It wish to eat rice porridge, honey balls, and soft.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.14_0: When it was ready, she took it away and ate it herself.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.15_0: When Thullanandā found out about this, she accused her, saying,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.45.19_0: for every statement he commits an offense entailing confession.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.1_0: At one time in Vesāli, a householder who was a supporter of Venerable Ajjuka had two children living with him, a son and a nephew.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.3_0: “Sir, please assign this estate to the one of these two boys who has faith and confidence.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.4_0: That householder had faith and confidence,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.4_1: Venerable Ajjuka assigned that estate to him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.5_0: Due to eating so little, and hit leaf-hut.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.7_0: “Venerable Ānanda, who is the father’s heir, the son or the nephew?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.9_0: “Sir, this Venerable Ajjuka has assigned our wealth to our housemate.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.13_0: On that occasion Venerable Upāli was siding with Ajjuka,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.15_0: “Ānanda, when one is asked by the owner to assign an estate to so-and-so, and one does so, what has one committed?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.16_0: “Nothing is done by a famous bitter than a woman.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.17_0: “Venerable Ajjuka was asked by the owner to assign an estate to so-and-so, and he did so.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.46.18_0: There’s no offense for Venerable Ajjuka.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.1_0: At that time in Benares, a family that supported Venerable Pilindavaccha was harassed by criminals,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.3_0: And Pilindavaccha set his psychic power on a stilt longhouse.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.4_0: People saw those children and said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.6_0: and they placed confidence in him.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.7_0: The monks complained and criticized them,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.8_0: “How can Venerable Pilindavaccha bring back children who have been kidnapped by criminals?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.47.10_0: “There’s no offense for one of supernormal powers.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.1_0: At one time the two monks Paṇḍaka and Kapila were friends.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.2_0: One was staying in a village and one at Kosambī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.3_0: Then, while the first monk was traveling from that village to Kosambī, he had to cross a river. As he did so, a lump of fat that had escaped from the hand of a pork-butcher stuck to his foot.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.4_0: He took hold of it, thinking, “I’ll give it to the owners.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.7_0: Then a woman cowherd who had seen him crossing said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.9_0: Thinking he was no longer an ascetic, he had sexual intercourse with her.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.10_0: When he arrived at Kosambī, he told the monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.11_0: They in turn told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.12_0: “There’s no offense entailing expulsion for stealing,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.48.13_0: but there’s an offense entailing expulsion for having sexual intercourse.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.1_0: At that time at Sāgalā, a monk who was a student of Venerable Daḷhika was plagued by discontent. He then took a turban from a shopkeeper and said to Daḷhika,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.2_0: “Sir, I’m no longer an ascetic; I’ll disrobe.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.5_0: After getting the turban brought, Venerable Daḷhika had it valued,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.6_0: For he who washed it off at the five months
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-pj2:7.49.10_0: The second offense entailing expulsion is finished.
